messageBody:
Questions below, answers immediately following, rest of original message
appended.

> (1) Is there a better way?
> (2) Will the variables defined in oneTimeSetup be in scope inside MyTest?
> (3) How can I reuse the fixture defined in this class for another set of
> tests?
> (4) Will the fixtures defined the suite's TestCase's still be created?

1) Yes, comment your code ;) Seriously, a better way to what? What is it
that you seek to accomplish? If, as the name AllTests implies, this test is
simply plumbing to run all of your tests, then you don't need a fixture.
You can remove the TestSuite wrapper and the oneTimeSetUp and
oneTimeTearDown methods. Simply have your suite() method return the
TestSuite to which you have added your tests, not the TestSetup wrapper.
2) Variables declared in a method are scoped to that method, so they are out
of scope outside of the method. Class that inherit from the class in which
your (public or protected) method is defined have acces to the method (and
therefore the effects of the variable), but the variable is still scoped to
the method and not beyond.
3) If you remove the TestSetup wrapper, then you won't have a fixture to
reuse in other classes. At my company, I created a zTestCase class that
extends TestCase. In my class, I define a generic fixture, and provide
convenience methods for manipulating that fixture. All of our tests (all
those that need the fixture) extend zTestCase. That way, our tests leverage
the fixture in their supers, and override oneTimeSetUp if they need to alter
the generic fixture.
4) Yes, unless their oneTimeSetUp overrides the setUp method, in which case,
no. Again, it depends on what you seek to accomplish.

Hope that helps,

_chas_
